results.title: The Builders
results.brief_description: A story without words of the construction of a building in Los Angeles, from the first truck taking excavated earth from the site to the last worker waxing the new floors.

results.title: The Buddha of Badamtam
results.creator_credit: Murad Ali, Biresh Paul and Afsana Babylon
results.brief_description: This documentary traces the journey of Indian artist Meera Mukherjee’s conception of a fourteen-foot high bronze Buddha sculpture in the Himalayas, a testament to great art and a message of peace. Filmmaker Murad Ali focuses on Mukherjee’s lifelong interest in Buddhism and the spiritual quest that took her to Ladakh, Lahaul, Spiti, and Japan in search of answers, attempting to reconcile Buddhism and art. Roshan Seth and Nafisa Ali Sodhi narrate the film, which intersperses black and white footage of Mukherjee at work with colour stills, and features some stunning Indian singing. When Mukherjee died whilst working on the piece on January 27, 1998, a slew of artisans laboured to complete and erect the enormous work.

results.title: The Right to be heard
results.creator_credit: Kay Donovan, Louise Hubbard and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Examines every person’s right to understand what occurs in court regardless of language. The use of interpreters is one way of overcoming this disadvantage.

results.title: Birthdays
results.creator_credit: Linda Rawlings, Michael Rogers and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Australians, from all ages, from all backgrounds, discuss mythologies and stories connected with birth, mothering and pregnancy. The video utilises the imagery of water to represent the foetal world of the womb. By contrasting stories of pain and joy; accounts from mothers and accounts from adults who have undergone re-birthing; and by contrasting different cultural experiences of birth, “Birthdays” ultimately is a testament to the crucial role, ideas surrounding birth and mothering have on forming individual and cultural identity.

results.title: Totally Gross Anatomy
results.creator_credit: Donald M. Cooper and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Our bodies are machines in motion, capable of sheer strength, complicated thought and graceful coordination all at the same time. This is due to a network of specialised systems and teams of organs that work in perfect harmony. This series investigates those major systems, using actual footage of working organs as well as clear demonstrations with everyday materials to illustrate both the way in which they function and the purpose they serve. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students.

results.title: The Story of a thing = La Storia di una cosa
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A theatrical interpretation by a community theatre group, of the experiences of Italian women migrants, and those of their daughters. Combines stage sequences and interviews to present an appeal to listen, with humour and pathos, from a section of the community which is rarely heard. Italian dialogue, English subtitles.

results.title: Lost wax memory
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Phillip Piperides, an Australian Cypriot is a sculptor in bronze. He explains the lost wax process of casting in bronze and explains the appeal of this particular form of sculpture. Shows examples of his work in Brisbane.

results.title: The Brothers Byrne
results.creator_credit: William Gough, Ian McLaren, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Torn between the world of their childhood and the world where they must mow live and work, two flamboyant Newfoundlanders pay a nostalgic visit to the deserted outport where they were born. This is their story, and the story of so many others who, like them, became victims of the Newfoundland government’s controversial Resettlement Program. Credits include: Photography by Kent Nason.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Gough, Ian McLaren, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Bones and muscles
results.creator_credit: Gail Prensky, JWM Productions and National Geographic Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Totally Gross Anatomy”.
Using 3D animation and x-ray footage, this video reveals the network of 206 bones and more than 600 muscles that combine to make up the human musculo-skeletal system. Students will investigate the composition of bones (the spongy inner layer, the compact outer layer and the types of marrow inside bones), and the importance of joints, tendons and muscles in ensuring that the skeleton not only gives the body a flexible framework, but also protects important internal organs. The video concludes with a series of assessment questions and answers designed to ensure that students understand basic concepts related to bones and muscles. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gail Prensky, JWM Productions and National Geographic Television

results.title: Didgeridoo in Deutschland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Take an Aboriginal musician and an Australian composer … put them in the middle of Europe and what have you got? If the composer is George Dreyfus, the musician is Richard Walley, poet and exponent of the didgeridoo, and the European country is Germany, you get a fascinating look at two individuals whose people have been persecuted but whose vastly different cultures can come together in a totally satisfying work. Made with the assistance of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
